title: The Red Eye Basic Algorithm
author: Clinical Decision Support
keyPoints: Always check visual acuity and pupil responses first
Pain and photophobia suggest serious pathology
Unilateral red eye with reduced vision needs urgent assessment
Consider infectious vs inflammatory vs traumatic causes

q1.text: Is there any reduction in visual acuity?

q2.text: Is there severe pain with photophobia?

q3.text: Are the pupils normal and reactive?

q4.text: Is there any corneal involvement (staining, opacity, foreign body)?

q5.text: What type of corneal pathology is present?

q6.text: Is there any pain or discomfort?

q7.text: What is the nature of the pain?

q9.text: What is the pattern of redness?

acute_glaucoma.text: URGENT: Acute angle-closure glaucoma. Immediate IOP measurement, topical and systemic pressure-lowering treatment. Emergency ophthalmology referral.

anterior_uveitis.text: URGENT: Anterior uveitis/iritis. Dilated examination required. Start topical steroids and cycloplegics. Same-day ophthalmology referral.

corneal_ulcer.text: URGENT: Corneal ulcer/infection. Take corneal scraping for culture. Start intensive topical antibiotics. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

corneal_trauma.text: Corneal abrasion/foreign body: Remove foreign body if superficial. Topical antibiotic, cycloplegic. Eye pad if large abrasion. Follow-up in 24-48 hours.

corneal_edema.text: Corneal edema: Check IOP, assess anterior chamber. May indicate glaucoma or endothelial dysfunction. Ophthalmology referral required.

posterior_pathology.text: Possible posterior segment pathology: Dilated fundus examination required. Consider retinal vascular occlusion, optic neuritis. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

scleritis_episcleritis.text: Scleritis vs Episcleritis: Phenylephrine test to differentiate. Scleritis needs systemic workup and treatment. Ophthalmology referral.

bacterial_conjunctivitis.text: Bacterial conjunctivitis: Topical antibiotic drops (chloramphenicol or fusidic acid). Hygiene advice. Review if no improvement in 48-72 hours.

viral_conjunctivitis.text: Viral conjunctivitis: Supportive treatment with lubricants. Highly contagious - isolation advice. May last 2-3 weeks. No antibiotics needed.

dry_eye.text: Dry eye syndrome: Artificial tears, lid hygiene. Avoid preservatives if severe. Consider underlying causes (medications, autoimmune). Ophthalmology referral if severe.

subconjunctival_hemorrhage.text: Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Usually benign, resolves in 1-2 weeks. Check blood pressure. If recurrent, investigate bleeding disorders.

allergic_conjunctivitis.text: Allergic conjunctivitis: Topical antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers. Identify and avoid allergens. Cool compresses for symptom relief.
